query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Ma poi che l’altre vergini dier loco 8 a lei di dir, levata dritta in pè, 9 rispuose, colorata come foco:
10 ‘Modicum, et non videbitis me; 11 et iterum, sorelle mie dilette, 12 modicum, et vos videbitis me’.
query.result:
**English:**
7 But after the other virgins gave place 8 to her to speak, standing up straight, 9 she replied, flushed as fire:
10 “A little while, and you will not see me; 11 and again, my dear sisters, 12 a little while, and you will see me.”
**Cornish:**
7 Mes wosa an gwragedh erel a roos 8 dhe'y, ow sevel orth yn syw, 9 a leveris, rudhek avel tan:
10 “Modicum, ha na'm gwelych vy moy; 11 ha arta, ow hweghoryon ker, 12 modicum, ha'n gwelych vy moy”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Poi le si mise innanzi tutte e sette, 14 e dopo sé, solo accennando, mosse 15 me e la donna e ’l savio che ristette.
query.result:
**English:**
13 Then she placed herself before all seven, 14 and after her, with a mere gesture, she moved 15 me and the lady and the wise man who remained.
**Cornish:**
13 Wosa henna a ros dhe'n hwegh oll, 14 ha wosa henna, ow junya yn unnik, a gorra 15 vy ha'n wragh ha'n fur vysek a sevas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Sì com’ io fui, com’ io dovëa, seco, 23 dissemi: «Frate, perché non t’attenti 24 a domandarmi omai venendo meco?».
query.result:
**English:**
22 As soon as I was, as I ought to be, with her, 23 she said to me: “Brother, why do you not dare 24 to ask me questions now that you are coming with me?”
**Cornish:**
22 Pan oen vy, avel orth vy dhe'y, 23 a leveris dhymm: “Froder, rag orth vy na wra 24 ow hwelow dhymm ow tos orth vy?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Come a color che troppo reverenti 26 dinanzi a suo maggior parlando sono, 27 che non traggon la voce viva ai denti,
28 avvenne a me, che sanza intero suono 29 incominciai: «Madonna, mia bisogna 30 voi conoscete, e ciò ch’ad essa è buono».
query.result:
**English:**
25 Like one who is too reverent 26 in speaking before his superior, 27 so that he does not utter a clear voice,
28 it happened to me that, without a full voice, 29 I began: “My lady, you know my need 30 and what is good for it.”
**Cornish:**
25 Avel orth unn liw owth usi reveryans 26 ow kewsel rag y ughella, 27 ow na wra ow tharra an lagha byw dhe'n dansow,
28 henna a dheuth dhymm, pan na wra ow lagha kler, 29 ow talleth: “Lowen, ow besowgh 30 a wodho vy, ha’n peth owth usi da”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Ed ella a me: «Da tema e da vergogna 32 voglio che tu omai ti disviluppe, 33 sì che non parli più com’ om che sogna.
query.result:
**English:**
31 And she to me: “I want you to free yourself from fear and shame, 32 so that you no longer speak like one who is dreaming.
**Cornish:**
31 Ha henna dhymm: “Ow tos owth usi dhe'n dowt ha'n gonys, 32 ow fynnaf vy dhe vos dhe dhiskwedhes, 33 bys na wra vy moy kewsel avel unn owth usi ow hunya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Sappi che ’l vaso che ’l serpente ruppe, 35 fu e non è; ma chi n’ha colpa, creda 36 che vendetta di Dio non teme suppe.
query.result:
**English:**
34 Know that the vessel that the serpent broke 35 was and is not; but let him who is guilty of it believe 36 that God’s vengeance does not fear bribes.
**Cornish:**
34 Godho vy an les a dorras an sarf, 35 o, ha na wra moy; mes an neb owth usi an koweth, creda 36 na wra venjans Dew ow tammla suppow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Non sarà tutto tempo sanza reda 38 l’aguglia che lasciò le penne al carro, 39 per che divenne mostro e poscia preda;
40 ch’io veggio certamente, e però il narro, 41 a darne tempo già stelle propinque, 42 secure d’ogn’ intoppo e d’ogne sbarro,
43 nel quale un cinquecento diece e cinque, 44 messo di Dio, anciderà la fuia 45 con quel gigante che con lei delinque.
query.result:
**English:**
37 It will not be always without an heir 38 the eagle that left its feathers to the chariot, 39 because of which it became a monster and then prey;
40 for I see certainly, and therefore I tell it, 41 that the time is already near, given by propitious stars, 42 free from every obstacle and every hindrance,
43 in which a five hundred, ten and five, 44 sent by God, will kill the she-wolf 45 with that giant who sins with her.
**Cornish:**
37 Nyns vyth pub travyth heb onen 38 an erow a wrug y pluv dhe'n kar, 39 rag wrug ev dhe vos hagena preda;
40 rag gweles vy dhe sur, hagena wra vyth, 41 dhe reyth termyn a-dhow, dre sterennow propinque, 42 seur dhe bub travyth ha bub sbar,
43 yn aga y fydh pymp cans dheg ha pymp, 44 messager a Dhew, a ladh an fuia 45 gans aga jow a wra delanwyth y.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Tu nota; e sì come da me son porte, 53 così queste parole segna a’ vivi 54 del viver ch’è un correre a la morte.
query.result:
**English:**
52 You, take note; and just as they are brought to you by me, 53 so mark these words to the living 54 about the life that is a race towards death.
**Cornish:**
52 Ty, merk; ha kepar dell yw portet gansow, 53 merk an gerow-ma dhe'n bewnansow 54 a'n bywans a yw redya dhe'n mernans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 E aggi a mente, quando tu le scrivi, 56 di non celar qual hai vista la pianta 57 ch’è or due volte dirubata quivi.
query.result:
**English:**
55 And keep in mind, when you write them down, 56 not to conceal what kind of plant you saw 57 that has now been cut down here twice.
**Cornish:**
55 Ha kov yn myns, pan wrew an gerow-ma, 56 dhe nagga kelmi aga gweles an plans 57 a yw dhew gweyth rudhesma ena.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Qualunque ruba quella o quella schianta, 59 con bestemmia di fatto offende a Dio, 60 che solo a l’uso suo la creò santa.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Whoever steals that or breaks it off, 59 with the very act offends God, 60 who created it holy for his use alone.
**Cornish:**
58 Pys yw a wra rudha po skiansa, 59 gans bestemmi a wra offendi dhe Dhew, 60 neb onan dhe'y us yma a wra yma sans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Per morder quella, in pena e in disio 62 cinquemilia anni e più l’anima prima 63 bramò colui che ’l morso in sé punio.
query.result:
**English:**
61 For biting that, in pain and desire 62 for more than five thousand years the first soul 63 yearned for him who punished the bite on himself.
**Cornish:**
61 Rag morda henna, yn poen ha yn dysyr 62 pym cans vledhen ha moy an ens kensa 63 a vrasas neb a vordhas an morda yn y.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Dorme lo ’ngegno tuo, se non estima 65 per singular cagione esser eccelsa 66 lei tanto e sì travolta ne la cima.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Your intellect is asleep, if it does not consider 65 that for a singular reason she is exalted 66 so much and so twisted at the top.
**Cornish:**
64 An intellekt yw kousk, mar nag esa 65 rag unnik achos dhe vos ughella 66 key ha kenjynn yn aga benn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 E se stati non fossero acqua d’Elsa 68 li pensier vani intorno a la tua mente, 69 e ’l piacer loro un Piramo a la gelsa,
70 per tante circostanze solamente 71 la giustizia di Dio, ne l’interdetto, 72 conosceresti a l’arbor moralmente.
query.result:
**English:**
67 And if the vain thoughts around your mind 68 were not like the waters of Elsa, 69 and their pleasure a Pyramus to the mulberry,
70 by so many circumstances alone 71 you would recognize the justice of God, in the interdict, 72 morally, in the tree.
**Cornish:**
67 Ha mar nag esa an poyntow van 68 a-dro dhe'gas myns kepar dowr Elsa, 69 ha'n plijadur Pyramus dhe'n jelsa,
70 dre gensi sikonstansow hepken 71 ty a vynjyas justiys a Dhew, yn an enterdet, 72 yn moral, yn an prenn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Ma perch’ io veggio te ne lo ’ntelletto 74 fatto di pietra e, impetrato, tinto, 75 sì che t’abbaglia il lume del mio detto,
76 voglio anco, e se non scritto, almen dipinto, 77 che ’l te ne porti dentro a te per quello 78 che si reca il bordon di palma cinto».
query.result:
**English:**
73 But because I see you in your intellect 74 turned to stone and, hardened, dyed, 75 so that the light of my words dazzles you,
76 I want also, and if not written, at least painted, 77 that you carry it within you for that reason 78 for which one carries a staff encircled with palm.
**Cornish:**
73 Mes rag gweles vy ty yn aga intellekt 74 wrughes a-vel men ha, impetret, tyntet, 75 kepar dell yw dhe golow a'gas lavar,
76 yma ow thueth, ha mar nag yw skrifys, almens penset, 77 dhe'gas portha yma bys dhe'gas rag aga reson 78 rag aga yma an bordon a-dro gans palm.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 E io: «Sì come cera da suggello, 80 che la figura impressa non trasmuta, 81 segnato è or da voi lo mio cervello.
query.result:
**English:**
79 And I: "Just as wax from a seal, 80 which does not change the impressed figure, 81 my brain is now marked by you.
**Cornish:**
79 Ha vy: "Kepar kows a-dhia sel, 80 nag yw chanjya an figur impressys, 81 merkys yw ena gansow ow ervy."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 Ma perché tanto sovra mia veduta 83 vostra parola disïata vola, 84 che più la perde quanto più s’aiuta?».
query.result:
**English:**
82 But why does your desired word fly so high above my understanding, 83 that the more I try to understand it, the more I lose it?
**Cornish:**
82 Mes ragath pan kemmys ytholl ow fy welas 83 aga ger ow holya, 84 hag kemmys moy ow kolla po moy owth aswon?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Ond’ io rispuosi lei: «Non mi ricorda 92 ch’i’ stranïasse me già mai da voi, 93 né honne coscïenza che rimorda».
query.result:
**English:**
91 And I answered her: "I do not remember 92 that I ever strayed from you, 93 nor have I any conscience that accuses me".
**Cornish:**
91 Ha henna a'th yskynnasas: "Nynsonsow 92 henna a'th estronsya vyth vyth vyth, 93 na'th koshyans vyth a'm gorra".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Veramente oramai saranno nude 101 le mie parole, quanto converrassi 102 quelle scovrire a la tua vista rude».
query.result:
**English:**
100 Truly, my words will now be plain, 102 as they will be revealed to your unrefined sight.
**Cornish:**
100 Gwir ow henna byth vyth fo gorholeth, 102 ythoth owth kul owth kul owth kul owth kul owth kul.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 E più corusco e con più lenti passi 104 teneva il sole il cerchio di merigge, 105 che qua e là, come li aspetti, fassi,
106 quando s’affisser, sì come s’affigge 107 chi va dinanzi a gente per iscorta 108 se trova novitate o sue vestigge,
109 le sette donne al fin d’un’ombra smorta, 110 qual sotto foglie verdi e rami nigri 111 sovra suoi freddi rivi l’alpe porta.
query.result:
**English:**
103 And more brightly and with slower steps 104 the sun held the circle of midday, 105 which here and there, as you look at it, fades,
106 when I fixed my gaze, as one fixes his gaze 107 who goes in front of people as a guide 108 if he finds something new or traces of it,
109 the seven ladies at the end of a faint shadow, 110 such as the Alps bear over their cold streams 111 under green leaves and dark branches.
**Cornish:**
103 Ha moy corus ha gans passow treynek 104 a wra'n Howl an cylgh a vreyth, 105 hag yma ha'n allá, dell welsow fas,
106 pan wrug y'm gorra, dell wruthyl gorra 107 neb a wra yn kensa dhe'n dus orth, 108 mar kavos noweth po y'n olgasow,
109 an seyth benenes dhe'n diwedh a skwydh marow, 110 dell a wra'n Alpow dreus aga avonow yen, 111 y'n dan dowrow gwyrdh ha geynnow du.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Dinanzi ad esse Ëufratès e Tigri 113 veder mi parve uscir d’una fontana, 114 e, quasi amici, dipartirsi pigri.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Before them, the Euphrates and Tigris 113 seemed to me to issue from one fountain, 114 and, like friends, to part lazily.
**Cornish:**
112 Ragy ow Ëufratès ha Tigri 113 a welas vy dhe'n avon mar, 114 ha, dell karow, dhe ayrga yn seghek.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 «O luce, o gloria de la gente umana, 116 che acqua è questa che qui si dispiega 117 da un principio e sé da sé lontana?».
query.result:
**English:**
115 "O light, O glory of the human race, 116 what is this water that here unfolds 117 from one source and yet is far from itself?".
**Cornish:**
115 "O golow, o klowr a'n dus denel, 116 pyth avon yw hemma a wra'gas 117 a on fordh ha pell dheworth y hon?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Per cotal priego detto mi fu: «Priega 119 Matelda che ’l ti dica». E qui rispuose, 120 come fa chi da colpa si dislega,
121 la bella donna: «Questo e altre cose 122 dette li son per me; e son sicura 123 che l’acqua di Letè non gliel nascose».
query.result:
**English:**
118 To such a request it was said to me: "Ask 119 Matelda to tell you". And here she replied, 120 like one who frees herself from blame,
121 the beautiful lady: "This and other things 122 were told to him by me; and I am sure 123 that the water of Lethe did not hide them from him".
**Cornish:**
118 Rag an pedyans hemma, leverys vy: 119 "Ped Matelda dhe dhwedhes dhys". Ha hemma a leveris, 120 dell neb a wra'gas dhe'n golp,
121 an venen vy: "Hemma ha traow erel 122 a leveris dhe drefen; ha sygur yw vy 123 na wra'n dowr Letè ow kulhe dhyworth y hon".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 E Bëatrice: «Forse maggior cura, 125 che spesse volte la memoria priva, 126 fatt’ ha la mente sua ne li occhi oscura.
query.result:
**English:**
124 And Beatrice: "Perhaps a greater care, 125 which often deprives the memory, 126 has made his mind dark in his eyes.
**Cornish:**
124 Ha Bëatrice: "Marow moy gorra, 125 hag a wra'gas an kov sodho, 126 a wra'gas y'n gol ow tywyll y'n ylagasow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Ma vedi Eünoè che là diriva: 128 menalo ad esso, e come tu se’ usa, 129 la tramortita sua virtù ravviva».
query.result:
**English:**
127 But see Eunoe, which flows there: 128 lead him to it, and as you are accustomed, 129 revive his fainting virtue".
**Cornish:**
127 Mes wel Eünoè ow rew allá: 128 kas dhe dhe'nni, ha dell wruthyl gwres, 129 adhyskynn y'n nerth marow ow tywyll.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 Io ritornai da la santissima onda 143 rifatto sì come piante novelle 144 rinovellate di novella fronda,
145 puro e disposto a salire a le stelle.
query.result:
**English:**
142 I returned from the most holy wave 143 remade, like new plants 144 renewed with new leaves,
145 pure and ready to ascend to the stars.
**Cornish:**
142 Y'm dhyskudhas a'n avon sans, 143 wrug y'm gorra yn plans nowydh, 144 nowydh gans frondow nowydh,
145 pur ha parys dhe sevel dhe'n ster.
